Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Story: I stared at my calendar, heart pounding. The family gathering had been planned for weeks—my daughter and her kids were so excited, and I’d promised to bake my famous apple pie. My granddaughter even called last night, asking if I’d braid her hair like I used to. But then, an email popped up: the team meeting was rescheduled to the same afternoon. It wasn’t just any meeting; it was the final discussion before we made decisions that would shape our project for months. My manager expected everyone’s input, and my colleagues counted on me to represent our department’s concerns. I could almost hear the disappointment in my granddaughter’s voice if I missed the gathering, but I also imagined the frustration of my team if I didn’t show up. The weight of both worlds pressed on me, and I felt torn, wishing I could be in two places at once.
